derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English smierwan (verb), smeoru 'ointment, grease', of Germanic origin; related to German schmieren (verb), Schmer (noun)

entry.def: If you smear a surface with an oily or sticky substance or smear the substance onto the surface, you spread a layer of the substance over the surface.

example.ex: My sister smeared herself with suntan oil and slept by the swimming pool...
example.tran: 我姐姐在身上抹了防晒油，躺在游泳池边睡着了。

example.ex: Smear a little olive oil over the inside of the salad bowl.
example.tran: 在色拉碗的内壁上抹一点橄榄油。

entry.def: A smear is a dirty or oily mark.

example.ex: There was a smear of gravy on his chin.

entry.def: To smear someone means to spread unpleasant and untrue rumours or accusations about them in order to damage their reputation.

example.ex: ...an attempt to smear the director-general of the BBC.
example.tran: 污蔑英国广播公司主管的企图

entry.def: A smear is an unpleasant and untrue rumour or accusation that is intended to damage someone's reputation.

example.ex: He puts all the accusations down to a smear campaign by his political opponents.
example.tran: 他把所有的指责都归结为政治对手们的造谣攻势。

entry.tran: 涂片检查(对妇女子宫颈取样检查癌变的一种方法)
entry.def: A smear or a smear test is a medical test in which a few cells are taken from a woman's cervix and examined to see if any cancer cells are present.

means.word_mean: 2. a thin tissue or blood sample spread on a glass slide and stained for cytologic examination and diagnosis under a microscope

sentences.sentence: "he had a smudge on his cheek"

means.word_mean: 4. an act that brings discredit to the person who does it;

sentences.sentence: "he made a huge blot on his copybook"

means.word_mean: 1. stain by smearing or daubing with a dirty substance
2. make a smudge on; soil by smudging
3. cover (a surface) by smearing (a substance) over it;
4. charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of someone;

sentences.sentence: "The journalists have defamed me!" "The article in the paper sullied my reputation"
